They call them time-out rooms; they have no doors.
They are attached to programs for childrem with emotional disturbance at elementary schools.
There is one room in the middle-school mental health unit.
They're called "calming rooms." Have some rules about how rooms are to be used.
They're not all at the ESC location; they're at the schools at which ESC behavior specialists are placed, including in South-Western and Reynoldsburg.
There are three. They're called "safe zone" rooms. They're also used as calming and sensory rooms.
District calls them "time-out spaces." Rooms are not locked. Separately, they have "sensory rooms."
Two rooms in programs for children with emotional disturbance, one at elementary school and one at middle school.
In 2011-12, began using a "quiet room" for students in district-run regional program for elementary-age children with emotional disturbance.
They will designate rooms as "calming rooms" but only if in IEP or behavior plan.
Operate a separate facility building for students with emotional disturbance in a building owned by Piqua school district. It has a "safe room."
One "time-out" room is shared between two classrooms for children with emotional disturbances in an elementary school. Currently developing policy on use.
One seclusion room shared between the junior high and high school.
ODYS provides educational services at juvenile correction facilities. Those facilities use seclusion.
One room used by program for children with emotional disturbance.
Two rooms for children in emotional disturbances program. Other rooms are used for other students and situations.
Eleven of 23 seclusion rooms used in 2011-12.
Not one regularly designated room; they sometimes designate rooms for this purpose. However, their policy bars placing children in small enclosed spaces.
They built two seclusion rooms in 2011-12. Currently using rooms and developing board policy.
Records refer to a "quiet area" or "quiet room."
In schools for children with special needs.
Four of seven existing seclusion rooms used in 2012.
They have rooms called planning centers. They have chairs and couches like family rooms. Not used primarily for seclusion.
They serve non-ambulatory, medically fragile children under age 3.
Do have "time-out" areas within the classroom.
Each of four classrooms has a "time-out area."
Does sometimes have children sit in the office for the day due to poor classroom behavior.
District contracts with local ESC for children with special needs; they don't have rooms themselves.
District contracts with local ESC for children with special needs, so they don't have rooms themselves.
pageTitle: Locked Away: See Which Ohio Schools Use Seclusion Rooms | StateImpact Ohio
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {290032=Note, Aug. 8: After this post was published, we received records requested from the Perkins Local school district. Perkins has a single seclusion room which is currently only used for one student with autism. The student is never physically forced into the room, according to the district’s superintendent. Perkins does not have a specific policy on the use of seclusion rooms.}
textBeforeTable: rows. 25 50 100 Show Filter: (Is your district not one of the ones we surveyed? Here’s how you can find out for yourself if a district uses seclusion rooms.) Click on the column headings to sort by category. Look up all the districts in a county by typing the county name into the search box. Look up a district, charter school or educational service center below by typing their name into the search box. How to use this table: Ohio School Seclusion Rooms Use this table to find out where your district stands. Only thirteen had policies governing their use. We found 39 of those 100 districts used seclusion rooms. The Columbus Dispatch and StateImpact Ohio surveyed 100 Ohio school districts, charter schools and educational service centers on the use of seclusion rooms in their buildings. Schools across Ohio, in rural, suburban and urban areas, use seclusion rooms.
textAfterTable: Previous Next Source: School district records | Download Data | About the Data Note, Aug. 8: After this post was published, we received records requested from the Perkins Local school district. Perkins has a single seclusion room which is currently only used for one student with autism. The student is never physically forced into the room, according to the district’s superintendent. Perkins does not have a specific policy on the use of seclusion rooms. Based on reporting by Jennifer Smith Richards of The Columbus Dispatch and Ida Lieszkovszky and Molly Bloom of StateImpact Ohio.
